notes_fields.Macroscopic_Features: Black apothecia up to 1.75 cm diam. with a matted, hairy exterior and a shiny, gelatinous interior; begininning urnulate, flaring out to be bowl-shaped then flattening to saucer-shaped; cap margin crenulate with orangish granules; pseudostipe tough, composed of wiry black hyphae reminiscent of the base of Urnula craterium.
notes_fields.Microscopic_Features:
Ascospores hyaline, uniseriate; beginning globose, maturing cylindrical to subfusiform; filled with lipid droplets; length (17.1) 19.7-23.7 (25.5) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 21.7 ¬µm; width (9.1) 9.9-11.6 (12.3) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 10.8 ¬µm; Q (1.7) 1.9-2.2 (2.4), xÃÑ = 2 (n = 30 measured in tap water).
Asci 8-spored, no opercula observed, inamyloid; length (334.4) 365.7-425.1 (429.8) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 395.4 ¬µm; width (14.8) 15-18 (18.9) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 16.5 ¬µm; Q (21.1) 22-26.2 (26.9) xÃÑ = 24.1 (n = 10 measured in tap water).
Paraphyses septate, even; width (1.8) 1.8-3.6 (4.1) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 2.7 ¬µm (n = 10 measured in tap water).
Ectal excipulum composed of melanized, thick-walled hyphae; width (4.6) 4.7-7.1 (8.7) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 5.9 ¬µm (n = 10 measured in tap water).

results.notes:
The morphology of these specimens accords well with Plectania melastoma according to Beug et al. (2014). I noticed the orangish granules after microscopy, which solidified the ID. The ascomata were found adhered to hemlock twigs, but not growing directly from them; rather, they seemed to arise from debirs on the ground and then fuse along the edge of twigs.

notes_fields.Macroscopic_Features: Basidioma smooth, resupinate, adnate, gelatinous when fresh, ceraceous when dry, up to 100 ¬µm thick, and somewhat transparent.
notes_fields.Microscopic_Features:
Basidiospores: ellipsoid, inamyloid, hyaline, uniseriate, with one or two large guttules; length (3.3) 4-4.7 (5) ¬µm, width (2.3) 2.5-2.8 (3) ¬µm, Q (1.3) 1.5-1.7 (1.8) (n = 30 spores measured in tap water).
Cystidia: occasionally present as leptocystidia (not encrusted), subulate, 3-5 ¬µm wide.
Hyphal system: a clamp connection was observed.

results.notes:
In classic phlebioid style, the hyphae and basidia were very difficult to discern becasue they were strongly adhered together. This character, along with the small, hyaline spores and gelatinous (when fresh) to ceraceous (horny hard when dry) texture indicates this is a Phlebia sp. The microscopic features fit Phlebia subulata well, according to Bernicchia and Gorj√°n (2010).

results.notes:
Habitat:
In a well manicured public park, growing in hardwood chips,in Portland Oregon.

Gills:
Color:dark brown /smoky brown.

Spores:
Dark brown. Interesting, I printed 15 mushrooms, but 8 did not drop spores. I waited over 24hrs and they never dropped. The others dropped within 4 hrs.

Stem:
White stem, semi-solid (see pictures)
Shortest stem was 1/4 in & longest was 2.5 in. All the stems were moderately thick, strong.

Cap:
Various size capes, the largest was 1.75in across. Various colors of brown to black to blue-ish green. The smaller specimens had a pointed Umbro, that flattened out with size. The caps became slippery, when I washed them, almost slimmy.

Bruising:
Nearly all of them bruised blue to a bluish green .

Other information:
The smell was distinctive but hard to describe. A bit earthy almost reminds me of Christmas dinner. They smell delicious, literally, they smell like they would taste amazing.

results.notes:
Pileus: 100 × 80 mm, dark brown with darker broad umbo, broadly convex, finely fibrillose, coruscate, radially cracked.
Lamellae: free, close, broad, pink.
Stipe: 70 × 15 mm, attenuate aloft, streaked with brown fibrils, context white and solid.
Spore Print: pink/mauve.
Spores: 5-9 × 4-6 ¬µm, subglobose, hyaline, multiguttulate.
Cheilocystidia: clavate, cornuate, 2-4 hooks.
Pleurocystidia: lageniform, 2-4 hooks.
Habitat: on rotting log, there were 3-4 much older basidiocarps grouped together which were growing roughly 2 feet down the log. Mixed hardwoods, mostly tulip poplar and oak, with occasional beech.

Note: even though the margins of the lamellae are not dark, I believe this is still Pluteus atromarginata based on microscopic features. If anyone feels differently, I’m open…

results.notes:
I was assuming that this was a crust, but I have seen pictures of Fuligo intermedia, including the spores, and this really looks like those.
Maybe 1/4" to 1/2" thick on rotten wood on the ground. Flat maybe 6 inches by 5 inches.
If you touch the spore mass, will immediately stain your fingers, black with a burgundy tone to it. Above that is gray to ivory.
Do the spores divide? The spores seem to be close to round to begin with, around 12×13 microns, but when splitting they can be 21 or 33 microns long, elongated or splitting with the shape of an eight.

notes_fields.Microscopic_Features: Spores: cylindrical to narrowly cylindrical in dimensions, curved (allantoid) in shape, hyaline, unseriate, biguttulate in water, inamyloid. Length (4.4) 5.2-6.1 (6.6) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 5.7 ¬µm; width (1.6) 2-2.5 (2.9) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 2.2 ¬µm; Q (2) 2.2-2.9 (3.4), xÃÑ = 2.6 (n = 30 spores measured in tap water). More spores observed in Melzer’s and were longer than those measured above, typically approaching 7 ¬µm long and up to 10 ¬µm long. Spores catenulate (i.e., born as chains), with the orientation of the curvature flipping with every spore resulting in a sinuous wave extending from a central, rudimentary conidiophore.

This lichen is above silica stones and dry moss.
Apothecia are less than 1mm

This lichen is above small stones with some dry grass and moss and has very weak fixation. Lower surface is light brown. Rhizines are brown and short. They are hidden inside the convex lobes and there is some old moss with soil in bottom side of lobes. Apothecia are absent, but usually many picnidia. C test made greenish-yellow tint, but medulla is white. K test on medulla shows orange-yellow then red up to dark blood-red.
Xanthoparmelia vagans according my guide books is similar to Xanthoparmelia wyomingica and they both have brown bottom surface.

notes_fields.Macro:
I collected three examples of this mushroom, all within 1m of each other. They were growing in low-cut grass and no trees or other woody vegetation was nearby. I am describing the most mature of the three examples.
Gilled mushroom with a convex cap. Cap color was off-white at top changing to tan at the margin. Smooth. This example was oval with a length of 5cm and a width of 4.4cm. Stipe was 5.7cm long and had a diameter of 1.0cm at the top and wider at the bottom. Stipe was solid inside and generally white. No change was noted after bruising. The odor was mild.
I have suggested that this specimen might be in the genus Agaricus based on general appearance and structure. I did observe some features that may suggest to experts that it is something else. The gills of the immatures were not the pink I normally see in Agaricus, but more tan or beige. The spore print was a light brown and not the typical dark brown. The gills were not as close as in our common A. argenteus. I collect specimens in the same area in February and sent a sample for sequencing (MO402428). That sample appeared to be contaminated because the sequence did not closely match any sequences at GENBANK. The earlier collections from this spot were degraded with age and I am not sure these fresh samples are from the same mycelium. I plan to sequence a sample of these new specimens to see what turns up.
notes_fields.Micro: I measured a few of the mature spores (see photo). Those measurements were: [n = 10] average 7.8¬µm (œÉ = 0.44¬µm) X average 5.16¬µm (œÉ = 0.23¬µm).

This isolated mushroom was growing in low-cut grass and no trees or other woody vegetation was nearby.
A gilled mushroom with a convex cap. The cap color was white with a diameter of 5.0cm. Smooth. Stipe was 5.0 cm long and had a diameter of 0.76cm in the middle of the length. notes_fields.Microscopic_Features:
Basidiospores: ellipsoid in dimension, lacrymoid in shape; hyaline, inamyloid, uniseriate, without guttules; length (7.3) 7.8-9.2 (10.4) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 8.5 ¬µm; width (5.4) 5.8-6.9 (7.9) ¬µm, xÃÑ = 6.4 ¬µm; Q (1.2) 1.3-1.4 (1.6), xÃÑ = 1.3 (n = 30 spores measured in tap water).
Basidia: terminal, often arising from small, squiggly hyphae; one developing basidium (with immature sterigmata) measured as 51.8 × 7.3 ¬µm.
Hyphal system: monomitic, clamp connections present at all septa; subicular hyphae width (3.6) 3.6-4.8 (5.4) ¬µm (n = 10 measured in KOH + phloxine); oily inclusions common in subicular hyphae (reminiscent of Sistotrema).

results.notes:
Growing abundantly among herbaceous plants in the floodplain of a creek. Veil present when young, leaving a wispy black ring zone on mature stems. Gills mottled. Caps glabrous and rugulose. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia cylindrical, hyaline and scattered. Cheilocystidia hyaline, capitate and forming facicles. Cheilocystidia measurements: (34.9) 48.3 – 79.3 (91.6) √ó (9.6) 10 – 11.7 (13.5) ¬µm, Q = (2.7) 4.5 – 7.3 (8.5); N = 30, Me = 62.9 √ó 11.1 ¬µm; Qe = 5.7. Basidia 4-sterigmate. results.notes:
Habitat: garden bed covered with purchased and native hardwood mulch, amended in previous years with Black Kow manure
Cap: diameters to 34 mm, conical at first then flattening with a broad umbo, moist, smooth, broadly banded in shades of yellow-brown to gray-brown with a whitened margin but not hygrophanous. Margin slightly striate or not striate, no pieces of attached veil
Gills: close, attached and with a vertical line down the stipe apex, broad, two tiers of short gills, initially whitish, darkening to medium brown with a whitened and sometimes finely serrate edge
Stipe: to 55 mm long, 5-8 mm wide at apex, narrowing below but with a basal bulb. Apically whitened and pruinose, browner and short fibrillose below. Bulb whitened. No evidence of partial veil. Hollow and somewhat cartilaginous
Flesh: buff, thin
Odor and Taste: distinctly farinaceous with a bitter undertone in the taste
Spore print: medium brown

results.notes:
Both found near edges of a dirt path under pine covered ‚Äúscrumps‚Äù or mounds.

Smaller one near cedar. Smells like cooked chicken liver to me. Pure white, compact tubes. Stipe is white to yellowish white with reticulation classic of porcinis.

Second one near ponderosa pine and a manzanita. Smells earthy. Stipe turned slightly light brown since it was picked four hours ago. Reticulation on stipe. Tubes underneath cap and brownish-yellow.

We were near 5000 elevation; soil temperature at the time was 52.5 degrees. The area had some dried out coral mushrooms nearby. Ponderosa pines, a few cedar, and manzanitas.

Realize these are boletes but not California Kings (stipes are too short). Any ideas, please? Much appreciated.
